comment: I really liked professor Clark. He is a behavior analyst for emory so he knows his stuff. Long lectures that can sometimes seem like rambling, but with lots of good info. He really enjoys the subject and teaching it. Talks super fast but doesn't mind if you ask him to repeat or slow down. The tests are tough.

The best professor I have had in college!  His lectures were interesting, gives good feedback, answers questions before you even have them, and he is super helpful to any students interested in the field of ABA.  He sets the class up to help students stay focused throughout the semester.  Weekly discussion posts, tests, and a paper are your grade!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--Amazing lectures

comment: This guy is the killer of GPA's. Be ready to take tests (which are online but still hard). He grades objective answers very harshly.  (This is coming from someone with a 3.7 GPA). For someone that preaches conditioning and works in that setting, his constant negative reinforcement thwarts a desire to put forth much effort.
rating_tags: Tough Grader--Skip class? You won't pass.--TEST HEAVY

comment: Great professor. His tests are online and open book but they're hard so you still have to study for them. He talks really fast during lectures but other than that he's really good. Knows his stuff and is willing to help if you need it.

Most people on here say he talks too much about behavior, but this class is literally called Learning and Behavior so I'm not sure what they expected. Online exams that aren't too hard if you know the concepts. This was a hybrid so 1 article to read per week and a discussion post. He's easy going and nice.

Seth's a nice person, but his lectures are fast & sometimes unclear. I wouldn't take this class as a hybrid b/c it is easy to forget what you learned from week to week. Lectures tend to go over time. He is a behavior data analyst, so he constantly talks about his job & seems to expect you to write  like one in your final paper. Pretty tough class.

The subject matter of this course is the most important you'll take as a Psych major. Behavior is everything - it's not just for taming autistic kids; look deeper.  Discriminative stimulus has 8 syllables - Prof. Clark pronounces it with 4, because he rushes his words. Rent the Cooper, Heron and Heward text - it's heavily referenced, and will help.

I like him! There are 4 online tests that are really quite easy. Big paper due at the end of the semester, but he has you submit it in increments and gives great feedback! Honestly, it's kind of hard to get a hold of the guy, but he eventually gets back to you. Lots of bonus opportunities. I took this as a hybrid, and I'd recommend his class.

THIS CLASS SUCKS!!! Unless you are obsessed with Skinner, because that is all this professor refers too. He's a nice enough guy but his grading is bias, all tests are tough. Zero help with the final papers. He says he's available but rarely ever responded to email. Unfortunately, this class could have been great but I am now turned off of all ABA.

RUN AS FAST AS YOU CAN IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION! I am an A student and this class was DECEIVING! Prof Clark is nice, but what good is that if the tests are open ended and he grades your responses HARSHLY? Don't get excited about open book tests, its hopeless with his grading. Lectures put you to sleep. The 4 tests are just horrid.

Seth is really passionate about the course and while the material is tough he is really willing to work with you if you're confused. Tough course but I would take it with Seth over other profs. Tests are online and you have study guides you can fill out beforehand. The class is hard but there are lots of extra points available so you can get an A.

Ehhh... Seth is OK. He is kind of cool but I honestly feels as if he makes the material far harder than it has to be. You have to pay attention in class and he makes you sign in everyday. His tests are online but they can be hard if you don't read. Overall, if you can avoid him then do so but he isn't the worst professor. Nothing personal.
